cbccore.low
Class Camera

java.lang.Object
  cbccore.low.Camera

public class Camera
extends java.lang.Object

Direct access to the CBC-C Camera Libraries

Documentation stolen from the KISS-C documentation

Author:
Braden McDorman

Constructor Detail

Camera

public Camera()
Method Detail

track_init

public void track_init()
Initializes the camera the necessity of this function has been questioned (although that was back on the XBC) and thus I am unsure if it is required. But give it a try anyways. Call this first!

track_is_new_data_available

public int track_is_new_data_available()
Determine if tracking data is available which is newer than the data processed by the last call to track_update().

Returns:
Some value other than 0 if true (probably 1), 0 if false

track_update

public void track_update()
Process tracking data for a new frame and make it available for retrieval by the other methods.

See Also:
track_is_new_data_available()

track_get_frame

public int track_get_frame()
Use to return value is the frame number used to generate the tracking data.

Returns:
the frame number used to genenerate the tracking code
See Also:
track_update(), track_capture_time()

track_count

public int track_count(int ch)
Use to return the number of blobs available for the channel ch, which is a color channel numbered 0 through 3.

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_size

public int track_size(int ch,
                      int i)
Gets the number of pixels in the blob.

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
the number of pixels in the blob
See Also:
track_init(), track_update(), track_bbox_width(int, int), track_bbox_height(int, int)

track_x

public int track_x(int ch,
                   int i)
Gets the pixel x coordinate of the centroid of the blob

(note: 0,0 is the upper left; 159x119 is the lower right)

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
he pixel x coordinate of the centroid of the blob
See Also:
track_init(), track_update(), track_y(int, int), track_angle(int, int)

(note: 0,0 is the upper left; 159x119 is the lower right)

track_confidence

public int track_confidence(int ch,
                            int i)
Gets the confidence for seeing the blob as a percentage of the blob pixel area/bounding box area

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
The confidence for seeing the blob as a percentage of the blob pixel area/bounding box area (range 0-100, low numbers bad, high numbers good)
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_bbox_width

public int track_bbox_width(int ch,
                            int i)
Gets the pixel x width of the bounding box of the blob. This is equivalent to track_bbox_right - track_bbox_left + 1

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
The pixel x width of the bounding box of the blob. This is equivalent to track_bbox_right - track_bbox_left + 1
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_bbox_height

public int track_bbox_height(int ch,
                             int i)
Gets the pixel y height of the bounding box of the blob. This is equivalent to track_bbox_bottom - track_bbox_top + 1

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
The pixel y height of the bounding box of the blob.
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_angle

public float track_angle(int ch,
                         int i)
Gets the angle in radians of the major axis of the blob.

Zero is horizontal and when the left end is higher than the right end the angle will be positive.

The range is -PI/2 to +PI/2.

If you don't know about eclipses you might start here or ask your local math teacher about major and minor axes.

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
The angle in radians of the major axis of the blob
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_major_axis

public int track_major_axis(int ch,
                            int i)
Gets the length in pixels of the major axis of the bounding ellipse If you don't know about eclipses you might start here or ask your local math teacher about major and minor axes.

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
The length in pixels of the major and minor axes of the bounding ellipse
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_minor_axis

public int track_minor_axis(int ch,
                            int i)
Gets the length in pixels of the minor axis of the bounding ellipse If you don't know about eclipses you might start here or ask your local math teacher about major and minor axes.

Parameters:
ch - from channel (range 0-3)
i - index (range 0 to track_count(ch)-1)
Returns:
The length in pixels of the major and minor axes of the bounding ellipse
See Also:
track_init(), track_update()

track_capture_time

public int track_capture_time()
Gets the timestamp (in milliseconds) of the current frame

Returns:
The timestamp (in milliseconds) of the current frame
See Also:
track_get_frame(), track_previous_capture_time()

track_previous_capture_time

public int track_previous_capture_time()
Return the timestamp (in milliseconds) of the previous frame, as captured by vision hardware. This is not necessarily the same as track_capture_time from the prevous track_update in the case where track_update was called less quickly than frames were captured and thus skipped one or more frame captures

Returns:
The timestamp (in milliseconds) of the current frame
See Also:
track_get_frame(), track_capture_time()
